questions.text: Splenic vessels are ligated at which level during Splenectomy?

options.label: D
options.text: Midway between hilum and pancreas superior border

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Superior border of Pancreas In elective splenectomy, the gastrosplenic ligament is opened up, and the short gastric vessels are divided. The splenic vessels at the superior border of the pancreas are suture-ligated. The posterior surface of the spleen is exposed, the posterior leaf of the lienorenal ligament is divided with long curved scissors, and the spleen is rotated medially along with the tail and body of the pancreas. The pancreas is separated from the hilar vessels, which are normally doubly ligated separately and divided. Accessory splenic tissue in the splenic hilum or omentum should be excluded by a careful search at operation. There is no need to drain the wound if hemostasis is adequate.

Highyeild:

In 75-85% of patients , splenectomy provides a lasting response that eliminates the need for further steroid treatment. Laparoscopic splenectom y has become the most commonly used surgical technique for treating idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura patients . Patients typically experience positive results within the first week after surgery. Patients with very low platelet counts (<10,000/mm 3 ) should have platelets available for surgery, but should not receive platelets before surgery. If bleeding persists after the splenic artery is tied off, platelets can be administered to the patient.

questions.text: The most common site of the Accessory spleen is the?

options.label: A
options.text: Behind the tail of the Pancreas

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Splenic hilum Splenunculi is single or multiple accessory spleens that are found in approximately 10–30% of the population. They are located near the hilum of the spleen in 50% of cases and are related to the splenic vessels, or behind the tail of the pancreas in 30%. The remainder is located in the mesocolon, greater omentum or splenic ligaments. Their significance lies in the fact that failure to identify and remove these at the time of splenectomy may give rise to persistent diseases like ITP.

Highyeild:

Splenunculi are single or multiple accessory spleens and are found in about 10-30% of the population The most common site of the accessory spleen is the splenic hilum, where the splenic vessels and the tail of the pancreas meet. Accessory spleens are typically small and round. They are usually asymptomatic but may need to be removed if they cause problems such as hypersplenism or are mistaken for other masses on imaging studies. Although accessory spleens can be found in other sites such as the mesocolon, greater omentum, or behind the tail of the pancreas, they are less common in these locations compared to the splenic hilum.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Options: A, B & C. Are not common sites of Accessory spleen.

Extraedge:

The significance of accessory spleens lies in the fact that if they are not identified and removed during splenectomy, they can give rise to persistent disease. This is because accessory spleens can continue to function and produce blood cells after the main spleen has been removed, which can lead to symptoms of hypersplenism such as anaemia, leukopenia, and thrombocytopenia. Therefore, it is important to be aware of the presence of accessory spleens and to remove them during splenectomy to prevent such complications.

questions.text: All of the following are true about Meckel's diverticulum except:
questions.correct_answer: C. Arises at the mesenteric border
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Arises at the mesenteric border Meckel’s diverticulum is found on the antimesenteric border. Meckel’s diverticulum: A Meckel’s diverticulum is a persistent remnant of the vitellointestinal duct and is present in about 2% of the population. It is found on the antimesenteric side of the ileum , commonly approximately 60cm from the ileocaecal valve and is classically 5cm long. A Meckel’s diverticulum is a congenital diverticulum. It contains all three coats of the bowel wall and has its own blood supply . It may be vulnerable to obstruction and inflammation in the same way as the appendix ; indeed, when a normal appendix is found at surgery for suspected appendicitis, a Meckel’s diverticulum should be looked for by examining the small bowel, particularly if free fluid or pus is found. In approximately 20% of cases, the mucosa of a Meckel’s diverticulum contains heterotopic epithelium of gastric, colonic or pancreatic type.

Highyeild:

Meckel's Diverticulum is the most common congenital anomaly of the small intestine, found in about 2% of the population. It follows the rule of two : 2% prevalence , 2 inches in length , half of the symptomatic cases are in children younger than 2 years old , 2 feet proximal to the ileocecal valve , It is a true diverticulum with all three layers of the intestine. It occurs due to incomplete closure of the omphalomesenteric or vitellointestinal duct and has an equal incidence in men and women The most common heterotopic tissue found in Meckel's Diverticulum is gastric mucosa (50%) , followed by pancreatic mucosa (5%) and rarely colonic mucosa. It is usually asymptomatic and discovered incidentally during the autopsy, laparotomy, or barium studies. The most common clinical presentation is gastrointestinal bleeding (25-50%) , with painless bright red blood from the rectum being the most common symptom in children younger than 2 years old. Chronic acid-induced ulcers in the ileum adjacent to a Meckel's Diverticulum containing gastric mucosa are the source of bleeding. Intestinal obstruction occurs in 31% of cases and is due to volvulus, intussusception, or, rarely, incarceration of the diverticulum in an inguinal hernia ( Littre's hernia ).

Random:

Explanation For other Options:- Options: A, B & D are correct statements.

questions.text: Bascom technique is used in.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pilonidal sinus The multitude of surgical procedures advocated to eradicate pilonidal disease, combined with the lack of prospective trials, attests to the lack of overall superiority of one method over the others. Time spent off work and perceived recurrence rates, but more usually surgeon preference, influence the choice of method, which includes the laying open of all tracks with or without marsupialization, the excision of all tracks with or without primary closure and the excision of all tracks and then closure by some other means designed to avoid a midline wound ( Limberg procedure, Z-plasty, Karydakis procedure ). Bascom’s procedure involves an incision lateral to the midline to gain access to the sinus cavity, which is rid of hair and granulation tissue, and excision and closure of the midline pits. The search for an ideal surgical treatment modality for the pilonidal disease is still ongoing, the most essential characteristic being tension-free healing.

Highyeild:

Surgical treatments for chronic pilonidal disease include: All tracks may be laid open with or without marsupialization. All tracks may be excised with or without primary closure. All tracks may be excised with closure by Limberg's flap, Karydakis flap, or rhomboid flap. Bascom's procedure involves making an incision lateral to the midline to access the sinus cavity, removing hair and granulation tissue, and excising and closing the midline pits. The lateral wound is left open.

questions.text: A 43-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of severe retrosternal pain radiating to the back and left shoulder for 4 hours. The pain began after attending a farewell party for his coworker at a local bar. He had 3–4 episodes of non-bilious vomiting before the onset of the pain. He has hypertension. He drinks 2-3 beers daily. His current medications include amlodipine and valsartan. He appears pale. His temperature is 37°C, his pulse is 115/min, and his blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. There are decreased breath sounds over the left base and crepitus is palpable over the thorax. Abdominal examination shows tenderness to palpation in the epigastric region; bowel sounds are normal. An ECG shows sinus tachycardia with left ventricular hypertrophy. An x-ray of the chest shows a left-sided pleural effusion and mediastinal widening. Treatment with intravenous fluid resuscitation and antibiotics is started. Which of the following is the most appropriate test to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

CT chest The patient's history of vomiting, alcohol consumption, signs of shock, and crepitus over the thorax raises concern for Esophageal rupture (Boerhaave Syndrome ). Diagnosis Chest X-ray: Hydropneumothorax The diagnosis is confirmed with a contrast esophagogram. This technique will demonstrate extravasation in 90% of patients. Gastrografin (water soluble) is preferred to prevent extravasation of barium into the mediastinum or pleura{less risk of mediastinitis}. If no leak is seen, a barium study should follow. Chest CT: Mediastinal air and fluid at the site of perforation. Endoscopy: If the esophagogram is negative or if operative intervention is planned The X-ray findings further support those diagnoses. CT scan of the chest is used to confirm the diagnosis of Boerhaave syndrome in patients who are hemodynamically unstable or otherwise not suited to undergo contrast esophagography. While bedside testing is usually preferred over a CT scan for unstable patients (e.g., TEE to confirm aortic dissection), there is no bedside imaging available to reliably confirm the diagnosis of esophageal rupture.

Highyeild:

Boerhaave Syndrome: Spontaneous rupture usually occurs on the left posterolateral side of the distal esophagus, into the left pleural cavit y or just above the gastroesophageal junction. Typically, male patients (85%) aged between 40 to 60 years with a recent history of vomiting are affected. Clinical Features Spontaneous esophageal perforation is characterized by Mackler's triad of thoracic pain, vomiting, and cervical subcutaneous emphysema. Thoracic perforations cause substernal and epigastric pain. While mediastinal emphysema and pleural effusions are common, early cervical subcutaneous emphysema is observed in only 20% or less of patients. Increasing contamination and inflammation of the mediastinum and pleural cavities lead to fever and sepsis . Patients with an abdominal perforation experience epigastric abdominal pain, which is also frequently referred to the back and left shoulder.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) may be used to diagnose Boerhaave syndrome if other imaging techniques are inconclusive. Because EGD increases the likelihood of esophageal leak, it is typically reserved for patients with poorly localized esophageal perforation and in whom endoscopic treatment is already indicated. Option: B. In the past, aortography was used to detect aortic dissection. This patient has severe retrosternal pain radiating to his back and is hemodynamically unstable, which may be seen in patients with aortic dissection. However, the patient's recent alcohol intake followed by several episodes of vomiting and the presence of crepitus over the thorax favour the diagnosis of Boerhaave syndrome, which is confirmed with a different method. Option: D. Abdominal ultrasound may be performed in the case of suspected acute pancreatitis. This patient had several vomiting episodes following alcohol consumption, accompanied by pain radiating to the back. This presentation may resemble that of acute pancreatitis. But the pain in acute pancreatitis is typically located in the upper abdomen, and the patient would not have crepitus over the thorax. These features support the diagnosis of Boerhaave syndrome instead, which is confirmed with a different method.

Extraedge:

The diagnosis of hydropneumothorax can be confirmed by performing a contrast esophagogram , which has a high success rate of detecting extravasation in 90% of patients. To avoid the risk of barium extravasation into the pleura or mediastinum, gastrografin (a water-soluble contrast agent) is preferred over barium. If the initial esophagogram is negative, a barium study may follow. Chest CT can also aid in diagnosis by revealing mediastinal air and fluid at the perforation site. Endoscopy may be necessary if the esophagogram is negative or if surgery is planned. Treatment involves immediate resuscitation, securing the airway, administering intravenous fluids, and starting broad-spectrum antibiotics.

questions.text: A 60 -year-old man is brought to the emergency department for the evaluation of worsening upper abdominal pain that he first noticed this morning after waking up. The pain is of tearing and burning quality and radiates to his back. Yesterday, he underwent an upper endoscopy and was diagnosed with gastritis and a large hiatal hernia. He has hypertension, hypercholesteremia, and a left bundle branch block that was diagnosed 5 years ago. The patient appears to be in mild distress. His temperature is 37.8°C, his pulse is 103/min, and his blood pressure is 135/89 mm Hg in the left arm and 132/90 mm Hg in the right arm. Cardiopulmonary examination shows crackling with every heartbeat{Hamman’s sign+}. Abdominal examination shows tenderness to palpation in the epigastric region; bowel sounds are normal. Chest x-ray shows a large hiatal hernia and mediastinal lucency. A 12-lead ECG shows sinus tachycardia and a left bundle branch block. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Contrast esophagography with Gastrografin Iatrogenic traum a is the most common etiology of esophageal perforation, e.g., following upper endoscopy, as seen in this patient. While this patient's x-ray findings and Hamman's sign already suggest pneumomediastinum , Gastrografin contrast esophagography is indicated as a confirmatory test to visualize the potential defect and assess its size and exact location. Gastrografin is preferred over barium as a contrast agent because it is water-soluble and less irritating ; extravasation of barium may cause mediastinitis and subsequent fibrosis. There is no free air under the diaphragms on CXR, thus gastric perforation is unlikely.

Highyeild:

Diagnosis for B oerhaave Syndrome: Chest X- ray : The presence of hydropneumothorax indicates possible esophageal perforation. The diagnosis can be confirmed through a contrast esophagogram , which is a technique that can detect extravasation of contrast material in 90% of cases. To minimize the risk of barium extravasation into the mediastinum or pleura, Gastrografin (a water-soluble contrast agent) is preferred over barium. If no leak is detected, a barium study may be conducted. Chest CT scan can reveal the presence of mediastinal air and fluid at the site of perforation. Endoscopy may be recommended if the esophagogram is negative or if surgery is planned.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. A contrast-enhanced CT scan of the aorta can be used to evaluate for aortic pathologies, e.g., aortic dissection. Although this patient has several risk factors for aortic dissection (e.g., hypertension, smoking) and tearing pain that radiates to his back, mediastinal emphysema would not be an expected finding in a patient with aortic dissection. Also, patients with aortic dissection often have asymmetrical blood pressure and pulse readings between the limbs. This patient's symptoms after upper endoscopy suggests another diagnosis. Option: B. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD ) should be delayed in this patient with suspected iatrogenic esophageal perforation as the endoscope and/or air insufflation may cause further dissection of the perforation. If esophageal rupture is suspected, diagnostic endoscopy is reserved for patients with a poorly localized esophageal perforation on standard imaging and in whom endoscopic treatment is indicated. EGD should be considered if this patient's symptoms of burning epigastric pain were due to worsening gastritis – however, mediastinal emphysema is highly suggestive of esophageal perforation. Option: C. Abdominal ultrasound is the most useful initial test for diagnosing acute pancreatitis. Although this patient's radiating upper abdominal pain and history of alcohol use may suggest acute pancreatitis, his normal lipase level makes pancreatic involvement highly unlikely. In addition, pancreatitis does not explain subcutaneous emphysema present on exam. An abdominal ultrasound would have limited utility in establishing the diagnosis in this case.

questions.text: During an endoscopic biopsy of a distal esophageal stricture, the patient complains of significant new substernal pain. He is hemodynamically stable. An immediate chest film reveals a small pneumomediastinum. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Esophagram with water-soluble contrast Pneumomediastinum after endoscopy is suggestive of perforation of the esophagus in the chest. Other etiologies of perforation can include spontaneous rupture of the esophagus (Boerhaave syndrome) or trauma. Diagnosis is typically confirmed and the location of the perforation can be identified with a contrast esophagram. Because some contained perforations can be managed nonoperatively, an esophagram can also be useful in determining operative strategy. A study using water-soluble contrast (such as a Gastrografin swallow ) is typically ordered initially; if no leak is identified, the study is repeated using thin barium . A water-soluble contrast is used initially because of concerns for mediastinitis due to barium in the presence of esophageal perforation.

Highyeild:

Chest X- ray : The presence of hydropneumothorax indicates possible esophageal perforation. The diagnosis can be confirmed through a contrast esophagogram , which is a technique that can detect extravasation of contrast material in 90% of cases. To minimize the risk of barium extravasation into the mediastinum or pleura, Gastrografin (a water-soluble contrast agent) is preferred over barium. If no leak is detected, a barium study may be conducted. Chest CT scan can reveal the presence of mediastinal air and fluid at the site of perforation. Endoscopy may be recommended if the esophagogram is negative or if surgery is planned.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Repeat endoscopy is generally not the test of choice following suspected perforation as the defect or the extent (ie, whether the leak is contained) may not be able to be identified, and air may dissect intramurally during the procedure. Options: C & D. Endoscopy may be useful in treating the perforation with an esophageal stent or with clipping, both of which are reserved for select cases. In other scenarios (such as after a traumatic injury), pneumomediastinum can result from injury to the tracheobronchial tree, so in those cases, bronchoscopy may be warranted as part of the workup. Laryngoscopy and fiberoptic bronchoscopy is not needed in this case.

questions.text: In endoscopic management of achalasia cardia, which of the following procedures has complication as the highest risk of perforation?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Balloon dilatation Endoscopic balloon dilation by exerting excess pressure or done forcefully has higher chances in comparison to other given options. Other options are procedures which have transluminal surgery involved like myotomy, using Botox does not have a lasting effect but does not involve forceful dilation.

Highyeild:

Pneumatic dilatation is a procedure used to treat achalasia cardia by stretching the lower esophageal sphincter ( LOS ) using a non-compliant balloon. The balloon is made of plastic (polyethylene) and has a precisely controlled external diameter . It is inserted over a guidewire and available in sizes of 30-40mm in diameter. The goal of the procedure is to disrupt the sphincter muscle and make it less competent, thereby improving the patient's symptoms. Perforation is a rare complication of the procedure, with an average reported incidence of about 1.9% (0-16%). The risk of perforation increases with larger balloon sizes and should be used cautiously for progressive dilatation over weeks.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Options: A, C & D . These procedures do not involve exerting excess pressure and hence have less risk of perforation.

Extraedge:

Studies have shown that serial pneumatic dilatation has similar efficacy to surgical myotomy in selected patients. Factors that predict optimal response include age, gender, degree of dilation, response to first dilatation, and achalasia subtype.

questions.text: The following radiograph of a 78yrs old male with difficulty in swallowing with on-off pain, he also experienced weight loss during this period. What is the most probable diagnosis with the help of the following radiograph.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Rolling hernia Rolling hernia (paraesophageal hernia) is which protrudes and rolls over the mediastinum and causes pressure on the lower end of the esophagus. The most common complication causing it is volvulus. The cardia region is not found in its normal anatomical position.

Highyeild:

Hiatus hernia is a condition where abdominal contents move into the mediastinum through the hiatal opening of the diaphragm. There are four types of hiatus hernia: sliding hernia, true paraoesophageal/rolling hernia, mixed sliding and paraoesophageal hernia, and type IV. Sliding hiatus hernia is the most common and is associated with GERD. Asymptomatic patients may have an incidental finding of hiatus hernia on chest radiographs or CT scans. Large paraoesophageal hernias can cause obstructive symptoms and may present as a surgical emergency if gastric volvulus occurs. Gastric volvulus can produce dysphagia, chest pain, and other complications, leading to impaired lung function.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B. Chronic granulation tissue formation due to tuberculosis of Lymph nodes which is usually appreciated at the mediastinum. Option: C. Epiphrenic diverticula is a large pouch at the lower end of esophagus. Option: D. The hiatus slides across it, here there is no protrusion of cardia region in mediastinum. Types of Hiatal hernia : Type I Sliding hiatal hernia (MC) Type II True paraesophageal herniaQ Type III Mixed paraesophageal hernia (I and II) Type IV Paraesophageal hernia containing other intraabdominal organs

Extraedge:

All symptomatic paraoesophageal hiatus hernias should be repaired, while the decision to repair an asymptomatic hernia depends on the patient's age and comorbidities. The surgical principle for repairing paraoesophageal hernia is similar to sliding hiatus hernia repair but more technically demanding.

options.label: C
options.text: Ring core consists of fibrous tissue and cellular infiltrate

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Proximal oesophagus The above image is of Schatzki’s ring which usually occurs at the distal esophagus in association with reflux disease. Antireflux therapy is the management.

Highyeild:

Schatzki’s ring A Schatzki’s ring is a circular narrowing located at the lower esophagus that restricts its distensibility in a concentric and symmetric pattern. It is found at the squamocolumnar mucosal gastroesophageal junction and affects both mucosa and submucosa. This narrowing comprises esophageal mucosa above and gastric mucosa below , lacks esophageal muscle and is not usually linked to esophagitis. A small hiatal hernia often accompanies Schatzki's ring. Clinical Features The primary symptom of Schatzki’s ring is dysphagia , which presents abruptly with almost complete obstruction and affects solid foods only. Some patients experience episodic aphagia, which is a temporary obstruction of the non-distensible ring due to large pieces of meat. Diagnosis Doctors diagnose Schatzki’s ring using a barium swallow test , with a type ‘B’ ring located at the gastroesophageal junction.

Random:

Explanation For other Options:- Options: A, C & D are correct statements.

Extraedge:

Treatment: Asymptomatic patients with Schatzki's ring do not need treatment. The best way to manage symptomatic Schatzki's ring without reflux is esophageal dilation to alleviate obstructive symptoms. If the ring is associated with proven reflux and mechanically faulty sphincter, antireflux surgery is the preferred treatment. Surgical excision of the ring is not recommended because it can result in severe esophageal strictures.

questions.text: A 55 yr old male presents with dysphasia with occasional pain, the sensation of obstruction foul-smelling breath. In contrast, chest radiographs revealed a large pouch at the distal end of the esophagus, which is most likely
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Epiphrenic diverticulum Epiphrenic diverticula is a large pouch with few symptoms. It usually occurs due to a loss of coordination in incoming pressure and relaxation of LOS leading to an outpouching.

Highyeild:

Epiphrenic diverticula are pulsion diverticula located at the distal 10 cm of the esophagus. They are commonly linked with esophageal motility disorders like achalasia or other causes of esophageal outflow obstruction. Barium esophagogram is a useful tool to detect the size and anatomical relationship of the diverticulum and screen for esophageal motility disorder. Fundoplication or repair of hiatus hernia may be necessary depending on the size of the diverticulum or associated conditions.

Free communication between trachea and esophagus is a type of congenital abnormality{Such fistula can also occur in malignancy} Option: C. Pulsion diverticula with underlying motility disorder {Pulsion diverticulum is a mid esophageal diverticulum seen in esophageal motility disorder.}

Extraedge:

Large diverticula require removal along with myotomy from the neck of the diverticulum to the cardia to relieve the functional obstruction. Laparoscopic approach is the preferred option to reduce morbidity.

Solution:

Esophageal endoscopy Endoscopy will be the next best step of management as it will help to visualize the foreign body lodgment as well as the removal of the foreign body.

A standard diagnostic upper endoscopy examines various areas of the upper gastrointestinal tract. The procedure carries low risk but requires extra care for patients with achalasia or obstruction. Carbon dioxide is recommended for insufflation in patients with suspected esophageal perforation or for prolonged procedures. Rigid esophagoscopy is rarely used and flexible endoscopy with an over tube is an alternative. Ultra-thin endoscopy can be used in patients with trismus or obstruction and can be performed in an outpatient setting. Image-enhanced endoscopy using digital image enhancement, narrow-band imaging, and chromoendoscopy improves diagnostic yield and sensitivity.

questions.text: A 55 -year-old man comes to the physician for recurrent heartburn for 12 years. He has also developed a cough for a year, which is worse at night. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years. His only medication is an over-the-counter antacid. His BMI is 31kg/m2 Vital signs are within normal limits. There is no lymphadenopathy. The abdomen is soft and non-tender. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. A complete blood count is within the reference range. An upper endoscopy shows columnar epithelium 2 cm from the gastroesophageal junction. Biopsies from the columnar epithelium show low-grade dysplasia and intestinal metaplasia. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Endoscopic radiofrequency ablation This patient's biopsy results reveal low-grade dysplasia secondary to Barrett esophagus. The risk for malignant transformation of this precancerous lesion to esophageal adenocarcinoma is ∼7% per year. Therefore, eradication of all areas of intestinal metaplasia via endoscopic mucosal resection and subsequent endoscopic ablation therapy to remove the existing dysplasia and decrease the risk of dysplasia recurrence is the treatment of choice in patients with low-grade dysplasia.

Highyeild:

Barrett's esophagus: Metaplastic specialized (intestinalized columnar) epithelium can replace the distal squamous mucosa of the esophagus as a response to chronic injury. This condition is also known as the columnar-lined esophagus. The most common type of columnar epithelium observed in this condition is the intestinal epithelium (intestinal metaplasia). Chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) is the usual cause of this transformation, which is often associated with a sliding hiatal hernia. Patients with Barrett's esophagus often have a long history of heartburn and other reflux symptoms, and experience more frequent and severe reflux episodes than most patients with reflux symptoms. They are more likely to be obese, male, and of white ethnicity. Barrett's esophagus is a significant risk factor for esophageal adenocarcinoma.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Endoscopic surveillance is an acceptable alternative to more invasive treatment options for patients with confirmed low-grade dysplasia, but it is no longer the recommended choice of management. Additionally, a repeat upper GI endoscopy should be performed every 12 rather than 18 months after the initial examination for early detection of progression to high-grade dysplasia or adenocarcinoma as soon as possible. Option: C. Esophagectomy is indicated in the treatment of esophageal adenocarcinomas in suitable surgical candidates and may be combined with neoadjuvant chemotherapy and/or radiation therapy in patients with submucosal invasion. However, it is a complex surgical procedure with considerable morbidity and mortality and, thus, should only be performed if there is no alternative therapeutic option. Since this patient's biopsy results show low-grade dysplasia of the esophageal mucosa rather than adenocarcinoma, less invasive treatment is indicated. Option: D . questions.text: A 4-year-old female child presented with rectal bleeding and Hb shows 4gm/dL. Diagnose the condition
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Meckel's diverticulum RECTAL BLEEDING: Unlike in adults, malignancy is an exceptionally rare cause of rectal bleeding in children. In newborns, the life-threatening causes are malrotation and necrotising enterocolitis, and in older infants and children, intussusception. The quantities of blood loss are small but the conditions are serious. Other causes include anal fissures, juvenile polyps and certain gastroenteritides (e.g. Campylobacter infection ). The 4-year-old patient who presents with haemoglobin (Hb) of 40 g/L will most likely have bled profusely from an ulcer adjacent to a Meckel’s diverticulum containing ectopic gastric mucosa. A technetium scan may confirm the presence of ectopic gastric mucosa. A Meckel’s diverticulum may also be complicated by an obstructing band between the diverticulum and the umbilicus, diverticulitis, intussusception, intestinal volvulus or perforation.

Highyeild:

Meckel’s diverticulum Meckel's Diverticulum is the most common congenital anomaly of the small intestine, found in about 2% of the population. It follows the rule of two: 2% prevalence, 2 inches in length, half of the symptomatic cases are in children younger than 2 years old, 2 feet proximal to the ileocecal valve, and it's a true diverticulum with all three layers of the intestine. It occurs due to incomplete closure of the omphalomesenteric or vitellointestinal duct and has an equal incidence in men and women. The most common heterotopic tissue found in Meckel's Diverticulum is gastric mucosa (50%), followed by pancreatic mucosa (5%) and rarely colonic mucosa. It is usually asymptomatic and discovered incidentally during the autopsy, laparotomy, or barium studies. The most common clinical presentation is gastrointestinal bleeding , with painless bright red blood from the rectum being the most common symptom in children younger than 2 years old.

Colonoscopy : Endoscopic assessment may demonstrate the necks of diverticula within the bowel lumen. A narrowed area of diverticular disease may be impassable because of the severity of the disease and there is a significant risk of endoscopic perforation. Colonoscopy in these circumstances requires judgement and experience. Biopsies may be taken if possible and corroboration with a barium enema or CT virtual colonoscopy is required. Excluding a carcinoma may not always be possible and may represent an indication for resection.

Colonic diverticula The sigmoid colon is the most common site of colonic diverticula. Diverticula occurs when mucosa herniates through the muscularis propria, usually where the nutrient artery penetrates the colonic wall, causing a break in the wall. Increased intraluminal pressure and low-fibre diets are factors that can contribute to diverticula formation. Diverticulosis is more common in the Western world and rare in underdeveloped and developing countries where diets are high in fibre and roughage . The muscular layers of the colonic wall can thicken in diverticulosis, especially in the sigmoid colon, which may precede the appearance of the diverticula. Barium enema is the preferred investigation for diagnosing colonic diverticulosis . The investigation of choice for diverticulitis is a CT scan .
